source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: In Zr-Nb irradiated at about $6 6 0 ~ \mathrm { \bf K }$ to a fluence of $\mathbf { 5 . 8 } \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n \cdot m ^ { - 2 } H o l t }$ EMP et al [14] observed the following: a very low density of coarse loops with $\langle a \rangle$ - type Burgers vectors, residual $\langle a \rangle$ and $\langle c \rangle$ component network dislocations from the initial cold work, and fine precipitates $( \sim 0 . 3 \mu \mathrm { m } )$ not present prior to irradiation.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk7
evidence_span: a very low density of coarse loops with $\langle a \rangle$ - type Burgers vectors

evidence_span: residual $\langle a \rangle$ and $\langle c \rangle$ component network dislocations from the initial cold work

evidence_span: Observation of ⟨c⟩ component dislocations, in addition to ⟨a⟩ - type loops and dislocations, in all of the alloys (excluding zirconium)

evidence_span: the strain contribution from loops is insignificant compared with the measured strains in all the materials except pure zirconium

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_030_chunk8

evidence_span: The present results clearly indicate that a changing solute concentration in Zr-2.5Nb affects the growth rate

evidence_span: Growth and growth rate in Zircaloy are continuously increasing with fluence up to 16.9×10²⁵ n·m⁻² and show no tendency to saturation in either recrystallized or cold-worked material

evidence_span: the growth strain magnitudes are similar for recrystallized and cold-worked Zircaloy, achieving positive strains of 1.5% and negative strains 2 to 2.5% at the highest fluences and temperatures

evidence_span: Post-irradiation annealing experiments at 788 and 873 K indicate only insignificant recovery of the growth strain (<0.05%) in both materials

evidence_span: The growth rate in Zircaloy increases sharply with temperature above about 670 K
